In geometric graph theory, a branch of [MASK], a polyhedral graph is the undirected graph formed from the vertices and edges of a convex polyhedron.
In computer science, a graph is an abstract data type that is meant to implement the undirected graph and directed graph concepts from [MASK].

In graph theory, a branch of [MASK], a squaregraph is a type of undirected graph that can be drawn in the plane in such a way that every bounded face is a quadrilateral and every vertex with three or fewer neighbors is incident to an unbounded face.
In [MASK], an incidence poset or incidence order is a type of partially ordered set that represents the incidence relation between vertices and edges of an undirected graph.

In graph theory, a branch of [MASK], the kth power Gk of an undirected graph G is another graph that has the same set of vertices, but in which two vertices are adjacent when their distance in G is at most k. Powers of graphs are referred to using terminology similar to that for exponentiation of numbers: G2 is called the square of G, G3 is called the cube of G, etc.
In graph theory, a branch of [MASK], the Herschel graph is a bipartite undirected graph with 11 vertices and 18 edges, the smallest non-Hamiltonian polyhedral graph.
